Training and drill of infantry can only improve our units so far.  Our infantry brigades could benefit from improvements to their small arms.  By developing new weapons for our troops, we will enable them to bring more firepower to bear against infantry and other soft targets.\n\nResearching this will not only provide boosts to certain support unit types, but will also help to unlock additional levels of other infantry unit types.

At some point our troops are going to have to hold key defensive positions.  If we develop new support weapons, our infantry brigades should be able to better defend themselves when being attacked.\n\nResearching this will not only provide boosts to certain support unit types, but will also help to unlock additional levels of other infantry unit types.

Against a prepared and dug-in enemy, our infantry brigades will often suffer high casualties when attacking.  Our recent experiments with integrating small artillery pieces into infantry brigades shows great promise.  They should allow us to suppress the enemy and suffer fewer losses when we attack.\n\nResearching this will not only provide boosts to certain support unit types, but will also help to unlock additional levels of other infantry unit types.

Our infantry may be facing increasing numbers of mechanised troops.  Our infantry's smallarms struggles to damage hard units, such as enemy divisions containing tanks and other vehicles.  If we research AT weapons to integrate with our infantry brigades, then they will be able to do more damage to that type of enemy.\n\nResearching this will not only provide boosts to certain support unit types, but will also help to unlock additional levels of other infantry unit types.

Fighting in mountains and hills places aunique strain on our ground troops and makes it more difficult to move and attack.  By skimming the best troops from our infantry, we should be able to train elite brigades to operate in the mountains.\nAlthough lacking some standard heavy equipment, these brigades will have specialized equipment and training that will allow them to excel in rugged terrain.

Naval landings against defended locations are risky and expensive in terms of casualties.  Training and equipping infantry units especially for this task allows us to perform amphibious operations more effectively.

The ability to build large transport aircraft opens up the opportunity to insert lightly-armed infantry behind enemy lines.  First we need to investigate the logistics of equipping and training such units.

Fighting at night is always a problem due to simply not being able to see things well.  However, our scientists believe that we can develop equipment to allow our troops to fight more effectively using specialised night-vision scopes.
The Light Infantry Branch will upgrade Light Infantry, Naval Infantry, Cavalry, Militia, Luftwaffe Infantry, and HQ defence units.
Small units containing highly trained and highly motivated elite soldiers who do damage to the enemy out of all proportion to their numbers.
By researching light, portable artillery we can provide some much needed artillery support for our mountain and airborne units.

The Infantry Branch will upgrade Garrisons, Infantry, Semi-motorised, Motorised and Mechanized Infantry.This also includes the attachment/battalion sized units and the various nation specific unique versions.
The Special Forces Branch will upgrade Marines, Mountain troops, Paratroops, Airborne Infantry, and Ski Troops and Elite Light Infantry.

Garrison (from the French garnison, itself from the verb garnir, "to equip") is the collective term for a body of troops stationed in a particular location, originally to guard it, but now often simply using it as a home base. This kind of unit is ideal to defend a port or a tactical/strategical important area.\nThe garrison is usually in a city, town, fort, castle or similar. "Garrison town" is a common expression for any town that has a military base nearby.

By providing enough vehicles to transport heavy equipment and infantry components, we can provide some much needed mobility to our infantry units. This tech also enables motorized anti-aircraft brigades to be built.

Motorised infantry units may be quick on open roads, but the troops need to get out when combat starts.  If we build specialised half-tracks and troop carriers, then new mechanised brigades will be protected by their armour.  We can also put heavy weapons on many of their vehicles.

Bitter experience has shown that a fortified enemy position or a river can cause an attack to falter.  Troops supported by engineers trained in the use of specialized equipment can overcome such obstacles more effectively than those without such units.

Obstacles such as rivers and fortifications may impede the advance of our forces.  Special equipment will allow them to breach such obstructions more effectively and contribute to the momentum of our attacks.
The enemy can create strongpoints to delay our troops.  Such fortified positions need to be assaulted by troops with special equipment designed to counter the defenders' advantages.

Maintaining civil order is an important function of the state.  Policing the civilian population properly reduces the opportunities offered to those who would cause the state harm by way of sabotage and revolt.

By equipping our troops with motorised vehicles they will be able to take full advantage of the road networks and thus move much faster.  They will also be able to carry heavier support weapons into combat.

The desert is a particularly hostile environment to fight in.  By developing new equipment for our troops the effects of dehydration and sunstroke will be lessened and our casualties due to attrition reduced.

The jungle is a particularly hostile environment to fight in.  By developing new equipment for our troops the effects of dehydration and heatstroke will be lessened and our casualties due to attrition reduced.

Mountainous terrain is a particularly hostile environment to fight in.  By developing new equipment for our troops the effects of the cold will be lessened and our casualties due to attrition reduced.
Arctic weather is a particularly hostile environment to fight in.  By developing new equipment for our troops the effects of cold will be lessened and our casualties due to attrition reduced.

Amphibious warfare requires unique temporary modifications to our equipment to enable it to function properly.  During a landing on a beach, sand and water can foul any weapon.  By developing such technologies our troops will be confident that their equipment will not fail.

Airlanding troops face particularly dangerous challenges.  Gliders provide them with lighter weapons and special equipment that allow them to deploy quickly.  By developing such a technology, airborne troops will remain effective for longer when surrounded by the enemy.
Each level of the Tech will trigger an event OOB containing between 1 to 3 Indian Army Units. These may include Garrisons, Infantry, Cavalry and various supporting units.

Each level of the Tech will trigger an event OOB containing between 1 to 3 African Army Units. These may include Militia, Light Infantry, Cavalry, and Mountain Troops alongwith the various supporting units.

We can take our knowledge from developing armoured cars and research combat brigades of tanks.  Light armour brigades have better protection than armoured cars, making them less vulnerable to small arms and other soft attacks.  They are also highly mobile and offer the ability to build divisions that utilise combined arms tactics.

To make the most of our light armoured brigades, they should have enough firepower to punch through enemy divisions quickly.  By developing new guns to mount on our tanks, they will be able to damage and destroy enemy units more quickly.  However this comes at the price of a little reliability, meaning we may lose more tanks to mechanical faults when we attack.

Mobility is a key criterion for any land unit, but especially so for our light armour brigades.  Recent advances in engine technology show we can improve the speed of these tanks.  However, the new engines may not be as reliable, especially when we are on the offensive.

As enemy weapons advance, they pose an increased threat to our armoured units.  If we research new armour for our light armoured brigades, this should help defend against these weapons.  New armour will mean divisions with these tanks will take fewer losses.  However, the increased weight of the armour does slow our tanks down.

All the firepower, armour and mobility of a tank is wasted if it is unreliable and breaks down.  If we develop new, more rugged designs and systems for quickly repairing minor problems, then our tanks will be more reliable.  This means that divisions with light armour brigades will take fewer losses, especially when attacking.

Our light tank designs combine firepower, mobility and defensiveness.  However, combat analysis suggests that they are too heavily geared towards mobility.  By trying to balance all three elements we should be able to produce a superior front-line tank.  However this will come at additional time and cost on the production line.

To make the most of our armoured brigades, they should have enough firepower to punch through enemy divisions quickly.  By developing new guns to place on our tanks, they will be able to damage and destroy enemy units more quickly.  However, this comes at the price of a little reliability, which means that we may lose more tanks to mechanical faults when we attack.

Mobility is a key criteron for any land unit and we must make sure our armoured brigades are not slowed down too much by their improved armour and weapons.  Recent advances in engine technology show we can improve the speed of these tanks.  However, the new engines may not be as reliable, especially when we are on the offensive.

As enemy weapons advance, they pose an increased threat to our armoured units.  If we research new armour for our units, then this should help defend against these weapons.  New armour means that divisions with these tanks will take fewer losses.  However, the increased weight of the armour does slow our tanks down.

All the firepower, armour and mobility of a tank is wasted if it is unreliable and breaks down.  If we develop new and more rugged designs and systems for quickly repairing minor problems, then our tanks will be more reliable.  This means that divisions with armoured brigades will take fewer losses, especially when attacking.

As enemy weapons advance, our tank brigades will inevitably start to become more vulnerable and suffer losses.  No nation can suffer the loss of too many such units.  Therefore we may want to consider developing heavy armour that will take fewer losses in combat.  However, these new units will be more costly to produce and run, and are not as fast as other tank brigades.

To make the most of our heavy armoured brigades, they should have enough firepower to knock back anything that opposes them.  By developing new guns to mount on our tanks, they will be able to wear down enemy units more quickly.  However, this comes at the price of a little reliability, which means that we may lose more tanks to mechanical faults when we attack.

Although our heavy armour brigades are slowed down by their improved armour and weapons, we should make sure they still have good mobility on the battlefield.  Recent advances in engine technology show we can improve the speed of these tanks.  However, the new engines may not be as reliable, especially when we are on the offensive.

As enemy weapons advance, they start to pose a threat to our heavy armour brigades.  If we research new armour for these tanks, then this should help defend against these weapons.  This will mean divisions with these tanks will take fewer losses.  However, the increased weight of the armor does slow our tanks down.

All the firepower and armour of a tank is wasted if it is unreliable and breaks down. If we develop new, more rugged designs and systems for quickly repairing minor problems, then our tanks will be more reliable.  This means that divisions with heavy armour brigades will take fewer losses, especially when attacking.

Armoured cars are the most primitive armoured units.  However, this does not mean they should get left behind as our technologies advance.  If we design new armour for them, then their divisions should take fewer losses in combat.

Although armoured cars' chassis are not designed to carry heavy weapons, that does not mean we can't improve their firepower.  By researching new weapon placements for our armoured car brigades they will do more damage to soft enemy targets.

As tanks are developed and infantry becomes increasingly mobile, our support brigades need similar mechanisation to fight alongside them.  Self-propelled artillery and tank destroyers provide fast and tough support brigades for our divisions.
Infantry tanks support infantry units to overcome field fortifications and provide mobile firepower to the troops.
Mounting AT guns onto a tank chassis provides a quick and cheap mobile anti tank weapon.
Researching and installing more advanced optics in AFVs gives a distinct advantage in combat.
Researching and installing radios in AFVs allows for much better coordination and more effective armoured tactics.

By taking the concept of the heavy tank to its logical limit, we can develop super heavy tank brigades.  These colossal tanks almost amount to mobile fortifications, and against almost all ground attacks their thick armour offers enormous protection.  Moreover, their massive guns pose a threat to anything that opposes them.  However, they are vastly expensive to build and operate and are still vulnerable to being flanked and to air attacks.

To make the most of our super heavy tanks, we must keep their guns at the technological forefront. These new guns will make sure nothing stands in the way of these tanks for long.  However, this comes at the price of a little reliability, which means that we may lose more tanks to mechanical faults when we attack.

We struggle to produce engines powerful enough to make our super heavy armour brigades sufficiently mobile.  However, recent advances in engine technology shows we can improve the speed of these tanks.  Unfortunately, the new engines may not be as reliable, especially when we are on the offensive.

Although the armour of our super heavy tanks is already very thick, there are still improvements that can be made.  If we research new armour for these tanks, then this should help them stay safe from most attacks.  This will mean divisions with these tanks will take fewer losses.  However, the increased weight of the armour does slow these huge tanks even further.

All the firepower and armour of a tank is wasted if it is unreliable and breaks down.  If we develop new, more rugged designs and systems for quickly repairing minor problems, then our tanks will be more reliable.  This means that divisions with super heavy armor brigades will take fewer losses, especially when attacking.

The Waffen-SS (German for Armed SS, literally Weapons SS) was the combat arm of the Schutzstaffel (Protective Squadron) or SS, a paramilitary organ of the Nazi Party. The Waffen-SS saw action throughout World War II and swelled from three regiments to over 38 divisions, and served alongside the Wehrmacht Heer regular army, but was never formally part of it.

The Guards title was awarded to units and formations which distinguished themselves during the Great Patriotic War by the order No.303 on the 18 September 1941, and were considered to have elite status.

Artillery is a class of large military weapons built to fire munitions far beyond the range of infantry's small arms. Early artillery development focused on the ability to breach fortifications, and led to heavy, fairly immobile siege engines. As technology improved, lighter, more mobile field artillery developed for battlefield use. This development continues today

Heavy Artillery is a class of large military weapons built to fire munitions far beyond the range of infantry's small arms. Early artillery development focused on the ability to breach fortifications, and led to heavy, fairly immobile siege engines. As technology improved, lighter, more mobile field artillery developed for battlefield use. This development continues today
Proximity fuzes greatly increased effectiveness of virtualy all artillery types. This type of fuzing was very effective against German V1's and against infantry.

The accuracy and tactics employed by our artillery brigades can only take them so far.  We can take our existing models and develop larger calibers of artillery and more powerful ammo.  This will enable our artillery brigades to increase the firepower they can bring to bear against enemy targets.

To be able to use our artillery to its full potential their shells have to be accurate in all circumstances.  If we research new technologies for sighting and targeting then our artillery brigades will be more effective.  This is especially useful in helping to suppress enemy attacks, lowering our casualties.  It should also enable us to do more damage to enemy mobile and armored units.

Even the best anti-tank weapons are useless if they can not hit their targets.  By investing in new anti-tank weapons and targeting devices, our anti-tank weapons will be better able to hit and damage enemy targets.  This should cause the enemy to be more cautious in their attacks and our units will take fewer losses.

Against thicker and more advanced armor, the penetration ability of anti-tank weapons is paramount.  By focusing our efforts on improved ammo, we should be able to improve our anti-tank brigades.  The new ammo will allow them do more damage to enemy hard and armored units.

Our ground forces can take heavy losses if attacked from the air.  By developing new anti-air weapons and ammo, our specialized AA brigades will cause more damage to attacking enemy planes.  This should also help to prevent the planes from damaging the rest of the division.

When not engaging enemy planes, our anti-air units can be put to use against ground forces.  By improving their sights and targeting equipment, our anti-air brigades will be able to function as light anti-tank weapons.  This will means their divisions will take fewer casualties and cause more damage to enemy units.

Standard artillery can be costly to build and has a limited rate of fire.  By combining our military knowledge of artillery and rockets, we will be able to build new rocket artillery brigades.  Rocket artillery will be cheaper to build and will be able to deliver more firepower quickly in battle.  This is especially useful for offensive campaigns.  The brigades themselves are cheaper to build.  However, their ammunition is more expensive to supply.

One key capability of rocket artillery is to deliver large amounts of explosives simultaneously.  If we introduce new launchers and more powerful rockets then this bonus will be multiplied.  This will mean our rocket artillery brigades will do more damage against enemy units.

One area where tube artillery is superior to rocket artillery is its accuracy.  If we improve our rockets' stability, targeting equipment and sights then this gap will be narrowed.  This will allow our rocket brigades to suppress enemy units and lower the casualties their division takes.

A biplane is a fixed-wing aircraft with two main wings stacked one above the other. The first aircraft to fly, the Wright Flyer, used a biplane design, as did most aircraft in the early years of aviation. While a biplane wing structure has a structural advantage over a monoplane, it produces more drag than a similar unbraced or cantilever monoplane wing. Improved structural techniques and materials and the quest for greater speed made the biplane configuration obsolete for most purposes by the late 1930s.

Although the principles of powered flight are well known, harnessing them for military use will involve some work. Working on designs for single-engine aircraft, we will be able to develop a basic interceptor to shoot down enemy aircraft.

With the development of an interrupter gear we are able to target opponents without damaging themselves. For much of the early history of the fighter aircraft this was limited to the propeller. This would change with the introduction of gun turret mounts on bomber aircraft. The increased speeds of the new monoplanes of the late 1930s meant that the time available to deliver a sufficient weight of fire to bring down an enemy was greatly reduced, and two guns were no longer enough. Since it was never practicable to mount more than two synchronized guns in the forward fuselage, any additional guns had to be mounted in the wings.

The Dam Buster Bomb was a bouncing bomb, which is a bomb designed specifically to bounce to a target across water in a calculated manner to avoid obstacles such as torpedo nets, and to allow both the bomb's speed on arrival at the target and the timing of its detonation to be pre-determined, in a similar fashion to a regular naval depth charge. The Tallboy or Bomb, Medium Capacity, 12,000 lb, was an earthquake bomb developed by the British aeronautical engineer Barnes Wallis and deployed by the RAF in 1944. It weighed five tons and, carried by the Avro Lancaster, was effective against hardened structures against which earlier, smaller bombs had proven ineffective. The last of the Kriegsmarine's Bismarck-class battleships, the Tirpitz, was sunk by an air attack using Tallboys.

The Grand Slam was a 22,000 lb (10,000 kg) earthquake bomb used by RAF Bomber Command against strategic targets during the Second World War. The Butterfly Bomb, or Sprengbombe Dickwandig 2 kg or SD2,  was one of the first cluster bombs ever used in combat and it proved to be a highly effective weapon. SD2 bomblets were not dropped individually, but were packed into containers holding between 6 and 108 submunitions. The submunitions were released after the container was released from the aircraft and had burst open. The bomb containers that carried the SD2 bomblets and released them in the air were nicknamed "the Devils Eggs" by Luftwaffe air and ground crew.

In the 1930s, Germany had experimented with the laying of mines by aircraft, it became a crucial element in their overall mining strategy. Aircraft had the advantage of speed, and they would never get caught in their own minefields. German mines held a large 1,000 pounds (450 kg) explosive charge. From April to June 1940, the Luftwaffe laid 1,000 mines in British waters. Soviet ports were mined, as was the Arctic convoy route to Murmansk. The Heinkel He 115 could carry two medium or one large mine while the Heinkel He 59, Dornier Do 18, Junkers Ju 88 and Heinkel He 111 could carry more.

Self-sealing fuel tanks have multiple layers of rubber and reinforcing fabric, one of vulcanized rubber and one of untreated natural rubber that can absorb fuel and expand when wet. When a fuel tank is punctured, the fuel will seep into the layers, causing the swelling of the untreated layer, thus sealing the puncture.

Aerial refueling, also referred to as air refueling, in-flight refueling (IFR), air-to-air refueling (AAR), and tanking, is the process of transferring fuel from one aircraft (the tanker) to another (the receiver) during flight. The procedure allows the receiving aircraft to remain airborne longer, extending its range or loiter time on station. A series of air refuelings can give range limited only by crew fatigue and engineering factors such as engine oil consumption. Because the receiver aircraft can be topped up with extra fuel in the air, air refueling can allow a takeoff with a greater payload which could be weapons, cargo, or personnel.

The radial engine is a reciprocating type internal combustion engine configuration in which the cylinders point outward from a central crankshaft like the spokes of a wheel. It resembles a stylized star when viewed from the front, and is called a "star engine" (German Sternmotor) in some languages. The radial configuration was very commonly used in aircraft engines before turbine engines became predominant.

In aviation, an inline engine is a reciprocating engine with banks of cylinders, one behind another, rather than rows of cylinders, with each bank having any number of cylinders, but rarely more than six.
Further refinements to our aircraft engines allow even greater speeds from our aircraft, although these new engines will consume more fuel and reduce our range.

A controllable-pitch propeller (CPP) or variable-pitch propeller is a type of propeller with blades that can be rotated around their long axis to change their pitch. If the pitch can be set to negative values, the reversible propeller can also create reverse thrust for braking or going backwards without the need of changing the direction of shaft revolutions.The first practical controllable-pitch propeller for aircraft was introduced in 1932. Such propellers are used in propeller-driven aircraft to adapt the propeller to different thrust levels and air speeds so that the propeller blades don't stall, hence degrading the propulsion system's efficiency. Especially for cruising, the engine can operate in its most economical range of rotational speeds.

A supercharger is an air compressor used to increase the pressure, temperature, and density of air supplied to an internal combustion engine. This compressed air supplies a greater mass of oxygen per cycle of the engine to support combustion than available to a naturally aspirated engine, which makes it possible for more fuel to be burned and more work to be done per cycle, which increases the power produced by the engine. Power for the supercharger can be provided mechanically by a belt, gear, shaft, or chain connected to the engine's crankshaft. When power is provided by a turbine powered by exhaust gas, a supercharger is known as a turbosupercharger  typically referred to simply as a turbocharger or just turbo. Common usage restricts the term supercharger to mechanically driven units.

Air cooling is a method of dissipating heat. It works by making the object to be cooled have a larger surface area or have an increased flow of air over its surface, or both. Air is mainly used for air-cooled internal combustion engines (ICE), particularly those powering aircraft, because it is a readily available fluid and is often at a suitable temperature to be used efficiently. While many such ICE are called "liquid cooled" the cooling liquid is usually cooled by air passing through a radiator or heat exchanger.

From the first days of military aviation, and even before military aviation became a reality, people understood that the protection of combat aircraft against enemy fire would be both desirable and very difficult. Armour plate is heavy, and its presence ate into the already very limited useful load and fuel capacity of the first aircraft. Moreover, the additional weight could make the aircraft unsafe, and present greater danger to the pilot than enemy fire would. And if the aircraft became too sluggish, the probability of it being hit by enemy fire would increase more than could be offset by the additional protection. Therefore, even when combat aircraft became bigger and more powerful, armour was usually designed only to protect the crew and the vital systems. The goal could not be to prevent damage to the aircraft

Aerodynamics, is a branch of dynamics concerned with studying the motion of air, particularly when it interacts with a solid object, such as an airplane wing. Aerodynamics is a sub-field of fluid dynamics and gas dynamics, and many aspects of aerodynamics theory are common to these fields. The term aerodynamics is often used synonymously with gas dynamics, with the difference being that "gas dynamics" applies to the study of the motion of all gases, not limited to air.

To decrease drag in flight some undercarriages retract into the wings and/or fuselage with wheels flush against the surface or concealed behind doors, this is called retractable gear. If the wheels rest protruding and partially exposed to the airstream after being retracted, the system is called semi-retractable. Most retraction systems are hydraulically operated, though some are electrically operated or even manually operated. This adds weight and complexity to the design. In retractable gear systems, the compartment where the wheels are stowed are called wheel wells, which may also diminish valuable cargo or fuel space.

The fuselage (from the French fusel "spindle-shaped") is an aircraft's main body section that holds crew and passengers or cargo. In single-engine aircraft it will usually contain an engine, although in some amphibious aircraft the single engine is mounted on a pylon attached to the fuselage which in turn is used as a floating hull. The fuselage also serves to position control and stabilization surfaces in specific relationships to lifting surfaces, required for aircraft stability and maneuverability.

A wing is a type of fin with a surface that produces aerodynamic force for flight or propulsion through the atmosphere, or through another gaseous or liquid fluid. As such, wings have an airfoil shape, a streamlined cross-sectional shape producing lift. A wing's aerodynamic quality is expressed as its lift-to-drag ratio. The lift a wing generates at a given speed and angle of attack can be one to two orders of magnitude greater than the total drag on the wing. A high lift-to-drag ratio requires a significantly smaller thrust to propel the wings through the air at sufficient lift.

In aeronautics, the rate of climb (RoC) is an aircraft's vertical speed  the rate of change in altitude. In most ICAO member countries (even in otherwise metric countries), this is usually expressed in feet per minute (ft/min). Elsewhere, it is commonly expressed in metre per second (m/s). The rate of climb in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). The rate of decrease in altitude is referred to as the rate of descent or sink rate. A decrease in altitude corresponds with a negative rate of climb.

A crew was formed by the pilot picking out each crew member from those available and the Operational Training Unit (OTU) they were posted too. OTUs were one of the final steps in an aircrews' training period before they reached an operational squadron. An Operational tour for a bomber crew consisted of thirty (30), non-aborted, operational sorties. Upon completion of their tour, the crew would normally be broken up and rested by being assigned to various Conversion or other non-operational units as instructors. It was not uncommon for a rested crew member to volunteer for a second bomber tour.

In telecommunications, identification, friend or foe (IFF) is an identification system designed for command and control. It enables military and national (civilian-located ATC) interrogation systems to identify aircraft, vehicles or forces as friendly and to determine their bearing and range from the interrogator. IFF may be used by both military and civilian aircraft.IFF was first developed during World War II. The term is something of a misnomer, as IFF can positively identify friendly targets but not hostile ones. If an IFF interrogation receives no reply or an invalid reply, the object cannot be identified as friendly but is not positively identified as a foe.The world's first IFF, FuG 25a Erstling" (English: "Debut"), was developed in Germany in 1940. It received the radar frequencies on 125 MHz (Freya radar) and 550-580 MHz (Wrzburg radar). To start the identification procedure, the ground operator switched the pulse frequency of his radar from 3,750 Hz to 5,000 Hz."

A night vision device (NVD) is an optical instrument that allows images to be produced in levels of light approaching total darkness. They are most often used by the military and law enforcement agencies, but are available to civilian users. The term usually refers to a complete unit, including an image intensifier tube, a protective and generally water-resistant housing, and some type of mounting system. Many NVDs also include sacrificial lenses, IR illuminators, and telescopic lenses.

A bombsight is a device used by aircraft to accurately drop bombs. Bombsights are a feature of most aircraft from World War I on, first found on the purpose-designed bomber aircraft, and then moving to fighter-bombers and modern tactical aircraft as these aircraft took up the brunt of the bombing role. A bombsight has to estimate the path the bomb will take after release from the aircraft. The two primary forces during its fall are gravity and air drag, which make the path of the bomb through the air roughly parabolic. There are additional factors such as changes in air density and wind that may be considered, but these are only a concern for bombs that spend a significant portion of a minute falling through the air.

Reflector sights were invented as an improved gun-sight and since their invention they have been adapted to many types of weapons. The earliest record of the reflector sight being used with fighter aircraft was in 1918. Reflector sights as aircraft gun-sights have many advantages. The pilot/gunner need not position their head to align the sight line precisely as they did in two-point mechanical sights, head position is only limited to that determined by the optics in the collimator, mostly by the diameter of the collimator lens. The sight does not interfere with the overall view, particularly when the collimator light is turned off. Both eyes may be used simultaneously for sighting.

A gyro gunsight (G.G.S.) is a modification of the non-magnifying reflector sight in which target lead (the amount of aim-off in front of a moving target) and bullet drop are allowed for automatically, the sight incorporating a gyroscopic mechanism that computes the necessary deflections required to ensure a hit on the target. The sight was developed just before the Second World War for aircraft use during aerial combat.

The windscreen projection endeavours to combine the four main functional aids into a single co-ordinated picture showing the pilot what is happening, and enable him to carry out the interception by its sole aid. The whole picture is therefore projected ahead of the aircraft, and observed by the pilot looking through his windscreen. The pilot sees the position of the enemy aircraft and its range, his own position relative to it, and his altitude in relation to the horizon and a pre-set heading, the whole being encompassed by the gunsight circle.

HUDs evolved from the reflector sight, a pre-World War II parallax free optical sight technology for military fighter aircraft.[2] The first sight to add rudimentary information to the reflector sight was the gyro gunsight that projected an air speed and turn rate modified reticle to aid in leading the guns to hit a moving target (deflection aircraft gun aiming). An early example of what would now be termed a head-up display was the Projector System of the British AI Mk VIII air interception radar fitted to some de Havilland Mosquito night fighters, where the radar display was projected onto the aircraft's windscreen along with the artificial horizon, allowing the pilots to perform interceptions without taking their eyes from the windscreen.

The first generation of jet fighters comprises the initial, subsonic jet fighter designs introduced late in World War II and in the early post-war period. They differed little from their piston-engined counterparts in appearance, and many employed unswept wings. Guns remained the principal armament. The impetus for the development of turbojet-powered aircraft was a decisive advantage in maximum speed.

With the advent of the guided missile, bombers had to turn to different ways to avoid interception. High speed and high altitude flying became a means of evading detection and attack. Some designs could fly faster or higher than contemporary fighters. Surface-to-air missiles threatened high flying aircraft, and bombers moved to high speed low-level flight to get under air defences.

An afterburner (or a reheat) is an additional component present on some jet engines, mostly military supersonic aircraft. Its purpose is to provide an increase in thrust, usually for supersonic flight, takeoff and for combat situations. Afterburning is achieved by injecting additional fuel into the jet pipe downstream of (i.e. after) the turbine. The advantage of afterburning is significantly increased thrust. The disadvantage is its very high fuel consumption and inefficiency, though this is often regarded as acceptable for the short periods during which it is usually used.

As jet engines propelled aircraft faster than ever before, aeronautical engineers realized that the density of air changes when it comes into contact with a moving object. At high velocities, this creates a buildup of high and low densities of air, resulting in a shockwave that can tear airplanes apart. The science of aerodynamics seeks to understand this phenomenon in order to better design supersonic aircraft.

The airframe of an aircraft is its mechanical structure, usually fuselage, wings, and undercarriage. The increased speed of turboprop and jet aircraft challenged to airframe designers to produce stronger and lighter airframes still. Modern jet aircraft wings needed to be both light and very strong to take advantage of the jet engine's potential for supersonic speed, but finding this balance proved to be extremely difficult.

The airframe of an aircraft is its mechanical structure, usually fuselage, wings, and undercarriage.  The increased speed of turboprop and jet aircraft challenged to airframe designers to produce stronger and lighter airframes still. Jet transport and bomber aircraft emphasize lifting power over raw speed, requiring a very specialized type of wing.

Avionics are the electronic systems used on aircraft, artificial satellites, and spacecraft.\nAvionic systems include communications, navigation, the display and management of multiple systems, and the hundreds of systems that are fitted to aircraft to perform individual functions. These can be as simple as a searchlight for a police helicopter or as complicated as the tactical system for an airborne early warning platform.

Cabin/Cockpit pressurization is used to create a safe and comfortable environment for aircraft passengers and crew flying at high altitude by pumping conditioned air into the cabin/cockpit. This air is usually bled off from the engines at the compressor stage. The air is then cooled, humidified, mixed with recirculated air if necessary and distributed to the cabin/cockpit by one or more environmental control systems. The cabin/cockpit pressure is regulated by the outflow valve.\nPressurization becomes necessary at altitudes above 12,500 feet (3,800 m) to 14,000 feet (4,300 m) above sea level to protect crew and passengers from the risk of a number of physiological problems caused by the low outside air pressure above that altitude

In aircraft, an ejection seat is a system designed to rescue the pilot or other crew of an aircraft (usually military) in an emergency. In most designs, the seat is propelled out of the aircraft by an explosive charge or rocket motor, carrying the pilot with it. The concept of an ejectable escape crew capsule has also been tried. Once clear of the aircraft, the ejection seat deploys a parachute. Ejection seats are common on certain types of military aircraft.\nThe first ejection seats were developed independently during World War II by Heinkel and SAAB. One of the He 280 test pilots, Helmut Schenk, became the first person to escape from a stricken aircraft with an ejection seat on 13 January 1942 after his control surfaces iced up and became inoperable.

A pressure suit is a protective suit worn by high-altitude pilots who may fly at altitudes where the air pressure is too low for an unprotected person to survive, even breathing pure oxygen at positive pressure.\nWith the development of higher speed monoplane fighters in the late 1930s, acceleration forces during combat became more severe. As early as 1940 some German aircraft had foot-rests above the rudder pedals so that the pilot's feet and legs could be raised during combat in an attempt to minimize the negative effects of high speed turns. Large rudder deflections were often not necessary during such manoeuvres, but being able to cut inside the opponent's turning radius was.

Subsonic (or low-speed) aerodynamics is the study of fluid motion which is everywhere much slower than the speed of sound through the fluid or gas. There are several branches of subsonic flow but one special case arises when the flow is inviscid, incompressible and irrotational. This case is called Potential flow and allows the differential equations used to be a simplified version of the governing equations of fluid dynamics, thus making available to the aerodynamicist a range of quick and easy solutions. Most often propeller-driven and commercial turbofan aircraft with high aspect-ratio (slender) wings, and rounded features like the nose and leading edges.\nAirspeed up to mach 0.8 (980 km/h).

The term Transonic refers to a range of velocities just below and above the local speed of sound (generally taken as Mach 0.81.2). It is defined as the range of speeds between the critical Mach number, when some parts of the airflow over an aircraft become supersonic, and a higher speed, typically near Mach 1.2, when all of the airflow is supersonic. Between these speeds, some of the airflow is supersonic, and some is not. Transonic aircraft nearly always have swept wings, delaying drag-divergence, and often feature design adhering to the principles of the Whitcomb Area rule.\nAirspeed between mach 0.8 - mach 1.2 (980 - 1470 km/h).

Supersonic aerodynamic problems are those involving flow speeds greater than the speed of sound. Supersonic flow behaves very differently from subsonic flow. Aircraft designed to fly at supersonic speeds show large differences in their aerodynamic design because of the radical differences in the behaviour of flows above Mach 1. Sharp edges, thin aerofoil-sections, and all-moving tailplane/canards are common. Modern combat aircraft must compromise in order to maintain low-speed handling

In aerodynamics, hypersonic speeds are speeds that are highly supersonic. In the 1970s, the term generally came to refer to speeds of Mach 5 (5 times the speed of sound) and above. The hypersonic regime is a subset of the supersonic regime. Hypersonic flow is characterized by high temperature flow behind a shock wave, viscous interaction, and chemical dissociation of gas. Cooled nickel-titanium skin, highly integrated (due to domination of interference effects: non-linear behaviour means that superposition of results for separate components is invalid), small wings, see X-51A Waverider and HyperSoar. \nAirspeed between mach 5.0 - mach 10.0 (6150 - 12300 km/h).

Modern ports are not simply places to load or unload cargo. Their construction requires detailed study in order to incorporate all of the equipment & systems needed to coordinate the flow of materials, personnel & vessels. Understanding port engineering will allow us to construct effective port facilities.
For the construction of ships a special dock is required that can drain all the water once a ship is inside the dock so that it can be repaired, enhanced or built.

The emplacements for coastal artillery are amongst the greatest works required of our construction engineers. Their effective placement, along with other, smaller emplacements for our defending infantry requires the study of coastal defence engineering. The emplacements for coastal artillery and more complex bunker-constructions are amongst the greatest works required of our construction engineers. Their effective placement, along with other, smaller emplacements for our defending infantry requires the study of coastal defence engineering. Once understood, we will be able to build effective defences for our defending troops & weapons.

Any defensive works more sophisticated than a simple slit-trench requires the input of an engineer to be effectively constructed. Even simple concrete machine-gun positions need to be designed & positioned correctly. Researching Land Defence Engineering will allow the use of modern building materials to be incorporated in our engineering works & fortifications.This technology allows for intricate Pillbox strongpoints
The construction of modern fortresses and powerful in depth defenses requires considerable construction expertise and materials. This technology allows fortress buildings to be constructed.

In order to operate modern aircraft effectively, airbases need to be correctly designed & built. By researching Air Field Engineering, we will be able to lay-out & construct the necessary runways, machine shops, hangars and other ancillary buildings necessary to support our aircraft.

Protecting our key installations and facilities will be critical if we are to succeed in our war efforts.  By researching the latest in installation security and facilities management, we can better insulate our ports, air bases, and other installations from unorthodox attacks, such as those from enemy commandos.

An army marches on its stomach.  If we aim to improve fertilisers, farm equipment and agricultural policies, we should be able to make better use of our arable land.  This will allow us to put more men into our armed forces.

The development of all-metal machine tools in the first two decades of the 19th century led to the manufacture of more production machines for manufacturing in other industries.  The effects spread throughout Western Europe and North America during the 19th century, eventually affecting most of the world, a process that continues as industrialisation.  The impact of this change on society was enormous.
Improving the organisation of our industrial zones will increase their output, but also their maintenance.

To make our place in the world our country needs educated individuals.  Instead of only assigning research teams to military projects, we can also assign them to educate others.  This will increase our leadership and provide better educated people for research, military officers, intelligence and diplomacy.

To make our place in the world our country needs highly educated individuals.  Investing in an advanced education system (colleges and universities), we can increase our leadership and provide better educated people for research, military officers, intelligence and diplomacy.

Medicine is the applied science or practice of the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disease.  It encompasses a variety of health care practices evolved to maintain and restore health by the prevention and treatment of illness in human beings.  By researching medicine we gain new techniques to cure even the worst diseases.

Casualties are a tragic consequence of war.  However, by developing combat medicine techniques and equipment, we should be able to help many injured troops, eventually allowing them to return to the front lines.

In hostile conditions we will always lose some men to the environment and minor injuries.  By improving basic first aid and medical procedures for our troops, we should be able to reduce their rate of attrition.
To fuel our war effort we need factories.  New construction techniques, if developed, will allow us to build more factories and increase our industrial capacity.

While industry helps create our forces and supplies them with equipment, it is our infrastructure that must move supplies and troops.  Advanced construction techniques will allow us to improve the infrastructure of our provinces.

Getting supplies from point A to point B itself, imposes a cost in supplies.  However, if we develop new vehicles and improve organisation for our transports, then the act of transporting supplies will consume fewer of them during transport.

There are only so many supplies we can move along any individual road or railway.  However, with better organisation we can increase that level, and this can be achieved by assigning teams to study the current state of our supply organisation.
Any plane, ship or vehicle will take damage at some point.  If we research civil defense it will allow us to better organise our home-front to repair equipment and reinforce our troops.

Radio waves of different frequencies can be used for other purposes than communications.  Scientists believe we could use them to help detect enemy units.  If we develop RADAR, then we will be able to build static RADAR listening installations.

Radio waves of different frequencies can be used for other purposes than communications. Our scientists believe we could use them to help detect enemy units. If we develop Air Warning RADAR then we will be able to detect enemy units early and scramble our interceptors sooner and intercept the enemy units before they do any damage.
Air search RADAR improves the ability of our aircraft to find the enemy.
Navigation RADAR improves the ability of our aircraft to know where they are.  This allows them to maintain formations better and improves their ability to attack and defend.

We are dependent on our industry to produce the supplies, weapons and equipment needed for our troops.  If we send teams to help our factories, then we will be able to make them more efficient.  This will raise our industrial capacity and allow us to produce more supplies and units.

Automation and mass production are vital to our war industry.  We cannot produce weapons efficiently enough by making them one at a time.  By researching ways to mass produce weapons, we will be able to produce more of them.
It is often hard to find enough oil for our vehicles, ships and planes.  If we can convert our abundant energy resources into oil more efficiently, this will aid our war effort.

Apart from food and ammunition our troops need lots of other items that are equally important during war - uniforms, shoes, blankets, tents, tools and many other items used each day on the frontlines.

To protect our cities, factories and military infrastructure from enemy air attack, we can deploy static batteries of anti-aircraft weapons.  To produce and improve these units, we should set teams working on developing new guns and ammunition for them.

Before we can start on many desirable projects, a sound understanding of electronic and mechanical engineering is required. Researching these subjects will give us improved theoretical knowledge in these areas and open up new areas of potential development.

Electromagnetic waves travel through the sky at near-instantaneous speeds.  Radio technology looks like it will be a key area to develop if we want to improve our intelligence and communications for our forces.  Unfortunately, the initial stages of development are unlikely to result in any direct military applications.\n- Each level gives -0.01 Encryption
Being able to hear what your enemy is communicating to his troops will be a big advantage in modern war.  Developing this tech will allow us to use our RADAR stations also as listening stations.

Communication and organisation are vital to any force in battle.  By providing our troops with radio communications they will fight more efficiently.  However, this may make them more vulnerable to our enemy intercepting their communications.

A census tabulating machine is a primitive card-operated mechanical device to aid the counting and recording of data.  If we set our research teams to develop census tabulating machines, they will be able to use them for future research projects.  This means that all future research will take less time.

Building on the idea of the census tabulating machine, different engines and other mechanical computation aids can be developed.  These computers allow our engineers and scientists to solve problems more quickly.  As such, they will increase the pace of all other research.

Mechanical computation machines are slow and may suffer from bugs when their parts get stuck or slip.  If we develop electronic components for our computing machines, they will run more efficiently.  This will speed up all our other research projects.

If we can know what our enemy's plans are, it will be much easier for us to defeat them.  If we apply our computing machines to try and decrypt enemy communications, then we should be able to develop new techniques for breaking their codes.  This will provide us with improved intelligence.

We must stop the enemy from discovering our plans and battle tactics.  If we apply our computing machines to devising better encryption methods, we should be able to develop more secure methods of communication that the enemy will not be able to intercept or understand.  This will mean the enemy will have less intelligence about our plans.

Designing new rockets is a hazardous, difficult and time-consuming task.  If we build specialised test centers, they will speed up our research.  However, we must first research the requirements for the test centers themselves.

Rocket power is an extremely powerful method of propulsion.  If we focus research to look at harnessing this power, it will open the gates to researching new engines to power giant missiles and planes.
Jet engines should allow aircraft to travel extremely fast.  By building on our rocket engine research, we should be able to develop proof of concept jet engines that can be applied to our planes.

Radioactivity and the atom are things we have all heard about, but from a military perspective they dont seem that useful.  However, there are physicists who claim that there are possible military applications for the atom.

Our atomic research has suggested the existence of previously unknown elements that do not occur in nature.  Our scientists believe that these unknown elements may provide the key to weapons of awesome power.

Further research has suggested that the isotope Uranium 235 may be the key to nuclear bomb production, and our scientists are asking assistance in creating a facility to separate this isotope from native Uranium metal.
Civil nuclear research allows us to build nuclear reactors of greater size and efficiency.  Our scientists also tell us that the biproducts from nuclear reactors will have some very interesting uses.

Crude oil is of limited use until it has been refined into fuel for our troops.  Advances in chemical engineering could help improve the efficiency of our refineries.  If we develop new technologies and plants to refine oil, then we will be able to produce more fuel from the same amount of crude oil.

Mining for ores can be a difficult process once the ore near the surface has been extracted.  Our improved understanding of chemical engineering means we may be able to improve our techniques and equipment.  We will then be able to recover more ore and produce more steel for our industries.

Rare materials are vital for our industries to run.  Studies from other chemical engineering projects show promise for helping get more out of them.  If we improve our refining techniques, then we will have more rare materials to send to our industries.

Our industries require vast amounts of coal and energy to keep running.  Our experience in chemical engineering shows we may be able do things more efficiently.  If we develop new processing techniques, we will be able to supply our industry with more power to keep the factories running.

No war can be won without ammunition and bombs. Each, even smallest battle requires sometimes thousands of artillery shells, hundreds of thousands rifle rounds, tens of tonns of bombs. Demand is extremely high and even brief shortages can have dramatic results.

It was Napoleon Bonaparte who purportedly said, An army travels on its stomach. Without food any unit, even well trained, elite or battle hardened will lose it's capability to be effective fighting force. Lack of food can shatter morale of soldiers faster than enemy bombs.
We need to develop a deeper understanding of aerodynamics.  This will enable us to construct prototypes to test our leading scientists' theories concerning rockets and their military applications.

Our scientists and engineers need to collaborate on creating a working production model of a flying bomb using the test data we've already gathered.  The experience acquired will prove useful in further rocket projects, and enable the construction of larger and more effective weapons.

Our scientists and engineers need to collaborate to create a working production model of a flying rocket using the test data we've already gathered.  The experience acquired will prove useful in further rocket projects, enabling the construction of larger and more effective weapons.

An efficient rocket engine will make it possible to launch long-range strikes on enemy targets.  The experience garnered from such research will also prove useful in the continuing development of these weapons.

A larger payload will allow our rockets to inflict heavier damage on the enemy's industrial capacity.  Research into this technology now will also make a contribution to further improvements in these weapons.

Experiments in metallurgical sciences will enable us to develop improved rocket designs.  Stronger materials will permit larger, longer ranged weapons.  These experiments will also contribute to our growing body of knowledge and make further research possible.

Our atomic weapons development is already in progress.  By devoting research here we will place ourselves in a position to produce an atomic device at an enlarged facility.  The research data gained here will be of great use later.

The development of these weapons will enable more effective air attacks against soft and hard targets.  Such weapons also open up possibilities for improvements in aircraft themselves.  Furthermore, such research will also contribute to our knowledge of rocketry.

Developing this technology will make aircraft more effective in the bombing roles assigned to them.  Such weapons also open up possibilities for improvements in aircraft themselves, as well as a more advanced understanding of aeronautics.
Researching torpedoes which home passively or actively on the sound of ships will increase the precision and lethality of the submarines.

By developing better techniques of medical evacuation, we will improve the morale of our troops, who will go into battle knowing that if they are injured they will be quickly treated at a remote hospital, rather than in the field.

By developing concepts of pilot rescue we will improve the morale of our pilots, who will go into battle knowing that if they have to bail out over the sea they will be quickly picked up by friendly forces.
Surface-to-air missiles will greatly assist the defence of the skies above our territory. Indirectly, they will also assist the development of our knowledge of rocketry.
Air-to-air missiles will help our fighter air defences by enhancing their attack capability.  Indirectly, they will also assist the development of our knowledge of aeronautics.
By focusing on ship building industries we can decrease the time and cost of naval vessels our ship yards produce.
By focusing on the aeronautical industry responsible for long range aircraft we can reduce the time and cost of these units.
By focusing on the aeronautical industry responsible for short range aircraft we can reduce the time and cost of these units.
Invasion planning is essential if we are to carry out successful amphibious assaults.  Using dedicated research teams in this area will allow us to learn from failure and enjoy success.

Research teams can be instructed to look at ways of increasing our officer recruitment.

This is a last ditch desperation tech to call to arms all men capable of bearing arms.  While it will massively increase our manpower it will have devasting effects on our industry and research.  Beware it cannot be undone!
Our research teams can investigate new tactics and theories in the increasingly important area of airbourne warfare.
By focusing on the home front we can increase our production efficiency, reduce waste and encourage everyone to give their all for the war effort.
This area of research will allow our special forces brigades to perform better in harsh environments.
By focusing on our artillery production we can decrease the time and cost of producing the Queen of the Battlefield!"
Research into the automotive industry allows us to decrease the time and cost of producing AFVs and motorised units.
By concentrating on the logistical side of warfare, we can improve our support for the troops on the battlefield.

The new weapons of armoured warfare require new operational methods. Warfare is now mobile, with fronts moving more in a day than they once did in a year.  Understanding this better will mean our troops are more likely to exploit breakthroughs they make, and our HQ brigades will also move faster.

In the last war we made much use of lines of trenches and fixed positions to stop the enemy.  Now, by holding the front lines lightly, with reserves sent to stop the enemy when he has committed his troops, we can conduct a more efficient, elastic defence.  This means our troops will be more likely to effect a tactical withdrawal when attacked and our HQ brigades will be better organised.\nThis tech also allows us to build motorized artillery brigades.

Our staff officers are experimenting with how best to employ tanks.  If we concentrate tanks in a small area, they can overwhelm the enemy and act as a powerful spearhead.  Making this our doctrine will make all our tank brigades much more useful because they will take up less combat width.

Our staff officers believe that the only way to win is by committing the maximum power to the crucial point, the "Schwerpunkt." With that approach we can easily achieve local superiority allowing us to launch successfull attack or hold defence line even if, in general, our army is smaller.

The doctrine of Blitzkrieg means using tanks to slice through enemy lines and manoeuvre behind the lines before he can react.  It requires well-trained armoured units working in nearly perfect unity with infantry and air support.

To control armoured operations, we need an effective command structure.  This means generals and their staffs who are well-trained and familiar with modern operational arts.  Focusing on this means that our units will be able to move more quickly on the offensive.

The lieutenants and sergeants who command platoons and sections are the backbone of our army.  Giving them better training and more authority is particularly important for modern mobile infantry warfare.  Doing so will increase the morale of our motorised and mechanised formations.

Often it is vital to hold up an enemy advance as long as possible while our commanders respond to events.  Focusing our officers on this will make it more likely that our units can slow the enemy down when attacked.

In the old days, the infantry and the artillery were separate formations, almost separate armies.  However, modern warfare requires close co-operation between infantry and their supporting artillery and anti-tank weapons.  Training in this co-operation will give us the opportunity to encircle the enemy more often, and make our HQ brigades slightly more effective against tanks.

During the last war, we relied on the morale of our infantry to seize the objectives.  It is a much more efficient way of fighting if the enemy has already been defeated by our firepower before the infantry advances.  Adopting this doctrine will mean that our main goal will be to simply bring as much firepower as possible to the battlefield, develop tools to do so (from small arms, machine guns to biggest artillery pieces) and proper tactics allowing us to fully utilize our superiority in that aspect.

With motorised and mechanised infantry units, we can conduct offensives far more quickly and powerfully than before.  However, this requires specialised training, and total co-operation between riflemen and their vehicles.  Making this part of the training regime will mean our mechanised and motorised brigades are more organised and effective in combat.

Tanks are very vulnerable on their own, while infantry often lacks the firepower to make a breakthrough unsupported.  To get the most out of our armoured formations, we must train tank crews and infantry to work together at the company and platoon level. Doing this means we will gain additional advantages for combined arms formations in battle.

The life of an infantry platoon is unglamorous but vital.  The tactics and training of our infantry can easily go unnoticed.  But if we pay attention to this area, our infantry brigades will be more organised and effective.

Our parachute, marine, and mountain formations are made up of our fittest men with the best morale.  However, they also need specialist training, since they are often called on to fight without the normal support.  Providing this training will mean our specialist brigades are more organised and effective.

Sometimes, the best way to take an objective is to storm it, regardless of losses.  This can overwhelm the enemy and shake their morale.  If we train our units to press on boldly towards the objective, they are more likely to conduct assaults.  Our HQ brigades will also be a bit more resistant to damage.

For an army to be effective in battle conditions, every unit must be working together towards a clear plan.  Making central control of all units our doctrine will mean there is a better chance of counterattacking against enemy attacks, and give our HQ brigades more toughness on the offensive.

The greatest generals have a grand plan for their battles, anticipating likely enemy movements and making sure there are enough of our troops in place to ensure victory.  Making this our doctrine will mean our divisions are more likely to reinforce the front line if there is space available.

Gone are the days when the enemy would march forward in a line for our artillery to shoot at over open sights.  Today's artillery warfare is all about calculating angles, examining weather conditions, and co-ordinating fire plans for an entire division or corps.  Training our gunners in these methods will mean our artillery brigades are better organized, with better morale.

Our army must be organised to attain its strategic objectives, not get bogged down with what each individual division is doing. Learning this will mean our divisions spend less time preparing between attacks.

The best way to beat the enemy is to fight over a very broad front, and switch the focus of our attacks from area to area to keep the enemy off balance.  If we focus more on this, our divisions will be better able to surprise the enemy with a shock attack.  HQ brigades will also consume fewer supplies.

Sometimes it is best to fight unconventionally, with small groups of troops roaming through the front lines, avoiding battles and causing mayhem.  If our army is prepared for this kind of guerilla warfare, then our units can inflict nasty ambushes on attacking enemies.  HQ brigades will also consume fewer supplies.

The Army is not just a body of soldiers, it is the expression of the will of our people.  Anyone can shoot a rifle or hurl a Molotov cocktail.  The more we prepare our citizens to defend the nation, the better organized our militia brigades and partisan uprisings will be.

If our army depends on masses of ill-prepared troops, it is vital that as many reach the front as possible.  This requires our staff officers and logistics experts to reconsider a number of their assumptions.  But if we do it, the result will be that militia and partisan units will be more effective in combat, because they will take up less combat width.

Even a well prepared enemy can be overwhelmed by a massed attack which offers him too many targets to deal with.  If our units become used to attacking in overwhelming numbers like this, they will suffer less of a penalty for having many divisions in the same province.

Once you begin a war you will be able to train your soldiers to take advantage of the delaying tactics Snipers afford the army in defense. This will show as a new combat tactic which may be used by your land forces in a battle.

The most obvious role for our aircraft carriers is as auxiliaries to the battle fleet.  We can train our aviators to locate enemy ships and damage them before a fleet engagement.  This will make carrier air groups more organised.
The light cruiser's main role is to escort other ships and make sure the fleet is not surprised.  Learning this will mean our light cruisers are better positioned and more effective in combat.

It is becoming clear that carriers are best deployed in carrier groups, supported by other ships.  This carrier doctrine will mean our carriers are better positioned and less likely to take damage in naval combat.

The light cruiser fills a vital role in our fleet.  Providing our light cruiser crews with improved training in scouting, screening and escort duties will mean that light cruisers are better organised and have better morale.

Aircraft Carriers fill a vital role in our fleet.  Providing our carrier crews with better training on handling planes and carrier strategy will mean the carriers are better organised and have better morale.

Carriers are increasingly becoming the core of our navy.  They are both so powerful and vulnerable that the first job of every other ship should be to support and protect the carriers.  This carrier doctrine will mean our naval units are more likely to try to protect our carriers when engaged by enemy surface fleets.

Modern naval warfare involves having large fleets away from their bases for extended periods.  To cooperate efficiently, we need to learn how to refuel, resupply and rearm ships while they are cruising at sea.  The more we do this, the easier it will be to send ships on long-range missions.
Although RADAR can detect things far away, it doesn't say what exactly we have detected.  By training our crews carefully, our carriers will be able to identify enemy ships a lot more quickly.

It is vital for our navy to protect our trade and supply convoys on the high seas.  The best way to do this is to construct purpose-built, cheap escort vessels which are too small and slow to serve with our fleet, but which can fend off an attacking enemy submarines or raiders. Establishing this doctrine will mean we can build escorts to protect our convoys.

An important role for our destroyers is to escort the fleet and screen it against enemy ships.  If our destroyer crews train and exercise for this role, they will be better positioned and more effective in surface combat.  Our convoy escorts will also become more effective.

The fate of our nation may well be decided by one great engagement between fleets of battleships.  Our battleships should practice squadron manoeuvres and mutual support so that they will be as effective as possible when that day comes.  This doctrine will mean our battleships are better positioned and more effective in all kinds of surface combat.

Destroyer crews have a difficult life.  Their ships are called on for dangerous jobs of every description, and they live in cramped, uncomfortable quarters.  We should focus on effective training our destroyer crews and give these small ships brave, charismatic officers.  This will result in destroyer units having better organization and better morale.

Most sailors dream of serving aboard the battleships, which are the pride of any fleet.  Nevertheless, good training is important, and regular battle drills are vital so our crews do not lose their edge.  Focusing on battleship training will give our battleships better organization and morale.
Our merchant ships are highly vulnerable to enemy submarines and cruisers on the high seas.  Making commerce defence the priority of our navy will mean our convoys are more difficult to attack.

It is diffficult to aim the guns on a warship. Both your ship and the target are moving quickly and at long ranges it can take minutes for the shells to arrive.  By training our crews to make use of mechanical rangefinders and firing computers, we will increase the chance our warships can fire effectively in battle.

In the smoke and haze of a naval action, it is not always easy to tell which ship you are firing at. We should give our captains clearer instructions and more authority to make decisions.  By doing so, we will find that our ships are more likely to engage more important enemy warships.

Our navy is just starting to experiment with how to use submarines.   We are first trying is to use them as auxiliaries to the battle fleet, distracting the enemy and sinking merchant ships.  Researching this will make our navy more effective at sinking enemy convoys.

We are coming to understand that the best way for submarines to operate is to sink enemy merchant ships far from land. Gaining experience in this area will make our submarines better positioned and more effective if attacked by warships.

The role of our battlecruisers and heavy cruisers is cruiser warfare, raiding enemy outposts and trade routes while avoiding battle.  The more training and experience we give our cruisers, the better positioned and more effective they will be in surface combat.

Submarine crews spend months at sea crammed into a tiny vessel, vulnerable to any passing aircraft or destroyer.  Yet they know their job is vital to the war effort.  Focusing on the training of our submarine crews and giving them officers who will be true wolves of the sea" will raise the morale and organisation level of our submarine crews."

The crews of our battleships and cruisers spend a long time away from home, but often the thrill of adventure makes up for that.  The more training we give our cruiser crews, and the more often we appoint bold captains who will strike at the enemy's sealanes, the more we will increase the organisation and morale of our battlecruisers and heavy cruisers.

At present our submarines are hampered by restrictions on which ships they can attack.  And some legitimate targets are missed because of doubt and confusion.  Introducing unrestricted submarine warfare means our submarine captains can sink any ship in enemy waters without warning.  This bold and decisive step would make our convoy raiding significantly more effective.

Standing watch on a warship is uncomfortable and boring, so it is easy to lose concentration and miss enemy contacts.  We can counteract this by giving warship crews better training and equipment for long-range spotting.  Doing this would mean our destroyers and cruisers would be better able to detect enemy warships.

HUDs evolved from the reflector sight, a pre-World War II parallax free optical sight technology for military fighter aircraft.[2] The first sight to add rudimentary information to the reflector sight was the gyro gunsight that projected an air speed and turn rate modified reticle to aid in leading the guns to hit a moving target (deflection aircraft gun aiming). An early example of what would now be termed a head-up display was the Projector System of the British AI Mk VIII air interception radar fitted to some de Havilland Mosquito night fighters, where the radar display was projected onto the aircraft's windscreen along with the artificial horizon, allowing the pilots to perform interceptions without taking their eyes from the windscreen.

The windscreen projection endeavours to combine the four main functional aids into a single co-ordinated picture showing the pilot what is happening, and enable him to carry out the interception by its sole aid. The whole picture is therefore projected ahead of the aircraft, and observed by the pilot looking through his windscreen. The pilot sees the position of the enemy aircraft and its range, his own position relative to it, and his altitude in relation to the horizon and a pre-set heading, the whole being encompassed by the gunsight circle.

A gyro gunsight (G.G.S.) is a modification of the non-magnifying reflector sight in which target lead (the amount of aim-off in front of a moving target) and bullet drop are allowed for automatically, the sight incorporating a gyroscopic mechanism that computes the necessary deflections required to ensure a hit on the target. The sight was developed just before the Second World War for aircraft use during aerial combat.

A night vision device (NVD) is an optical instrument that allows images to be produced in levels of light approaching total darkness. They are most often used by the military and law enforcement agencies, but are available to civilian users. The term usually refers to a complete unit, including an image intensifier tube, a protective and generally water-resistant housing, and some type of mounting system. Many NVDs also include sacrificial lenses, IR illuminators, and telescopic lenses.

Reflector sights were invented as an improved gun-sight and since their invention they have been adapted to many types of weapons. The earliest record of the reflector sight being used with fighter aircraft was in 1918. Reflector sights as aircraft gun-sights have many advantages. The pilot/gunner need not position their head to align the sight line precisely as they did in two-point mechanical sights, head position is only limited to that determined by the optics in the collimator, mostly by the diameter of the collimator lens. The sight does not interfere with the overall view, particularly when the collimator light is turned off. Both eyes may be used simultaneously for sighting.

In telecommunications, identification, friend or foe (IFF) is an identification system designed for command and control. It enables military and national (civilian-located ATC) interrogation systems to identify aircraft, vehicles or forces as friendly and to determine their bearing and range from the interrogator. IFF may be used by both military and civilian aircraft.IFF was first developed during World War II. The term is something of a misnomer, as IFF can positively identify friendly targets but not hostile ones. If an IFF interrogation receives no reply or an invalid reply, the object cannot be identified as friendly but is not positively identified as a foe.The world's first IFF, FuG 25a Erstling" (English: "Debut"), was developed in Germany in 1940. It received the radar frequencies on 125 MHz (Freya radar) and 550-580 MHz (Wrzburg radar). To start the identification procedure, the ground operator switched the pulse frequency of his radar from 3,750 Hz to 5,000 Hz."
