A wing is a type of fin with a surface that produces aerodynamic force for flight or propulsion through the atmosphere, or through another gaseous or liquid fluid. As such, wings have an airfoil shape, a streamlined cross-sectional shape producing lift. A wing's aerodynamic quality is expressed as its lift-to-drag ratio. The lift a wing generates at a given speed and angle of attack can be one to two orders of magnitude greater than the total drag on the wing. A high lift-to-drag ratio requires a significantly smaller thrust to propel the wings through the air at sufficient lift.

The fuselage (from the French fusel "spindle-shaped") is an aircraft's main body section that holds crew and passengers or cargo. In single-engine aircraft it will usually contain an engine, although in some amphibious aircraft the single engine is mounted on a pylon attached to the fuselage which in turn is used as a floating hull. The fuselage also serves to position control and stabilization surfaces in specific relationships to lifting surfaces, required for aircraft stability and maneuverability.

Aerodynamics, is a branch of dynamics concerned with studying the motion of air, particularly when it interacts with a solid object, such as an airplane wing. Aerodynamics is a sub-field of fluid dynamics and gas dynamics, and many aspects of aerodynamics theory are common to these fields. The term aerodynamics is often used synonymously with gas dynamics, with the difference being that "gas dynamics" applies to the study of the motion of all gases, not limited to air.

From the first days of military aviation, and even before military aviation became a reality, people understood that the protection of combat aircraft against enemy fire would be both desirable and very difficult. Armour plate is heavy, and its presence ate into the already very limited useful load and fuel capacity of the first aircraft. Moreover, the additional weight could make the aircraft unsafe, and present greater danger to the pilot than enemy fire would. And if the aircraft became too sluggish, the probability of it being hit by enemy fire would increase more than could be offset by the additional protection. Therefore, even when combat aircraft became bigger and more powerful, armour was usually designed only to protect the crew and the vital systems. The goal could not be to prevent damage to the aircraft

To decrease drag in flight some undercarriages retract into the wings and/or fuselage with wheels flush against the surface or concealed behind doors, this is called retractable gear. If the wheels rest protruding and partially exposed to the airstream after being retracted, the system is called semi-retractable. Most retraction systems are hydraulically operated, though some are electrically operated or even manually operated. This adds weight and complexity to the design. In retractable gear systems, the compartment where the wheels are stowed are called wheel wells, which may also diminish valuable cargo or fuel space.

Air cooling is a method of dissipating heat. It works by making the object to be cooled have a larger surface area or have an increased flow of air over its surface, or both. Air is mainly used for air-cooled internal combustion engines (ICE), particularly those powering aircraft, because it is a readily available fluid and is often at a suitable temperature to be used efficiently. While many such ICE are called "liquid cooled" the cooling liquid is usually cooled by air passing through a radiator or heat exchanger.

A supercharger is an air compressor used to increase the pressure, temperature, and density of air supplied to an internal combustion engine. This compressed air supplies a greater mass of oxygen per cycle of the engine to support combustion than available to a naturally aspirated engine, which makes it possible for more fuel to be burned and more work to be done per cycle, which increases the power produced by the engine. Power for the supercharger can be provided mechanically by a belt, gear, shaft, or chain connected to the engine's crankshaft. When power is provided by a turbine powered by exhaust gas, a supercharger is known as a turbosupercharger  typically referred to simply as a turbocharger or just turbo. Common usage restricts the term supercharger to mechanically driven units.

A controllable-pitch propeller (CPP) or variable-pitch propeller is a type of propeller with blades that can be rotated around their long axis to change their pitch. If the pitch can be set to negative values, the reversible propeller can also create reverse thrust for braking or going backwards without the need of changing the direction of shaft revolutions.The first practical controllable-pitch propeller for aircraft was introduced in 1932. Such propellers are used in propeller-driven aircraft to adapt the propeller to different thrust levels and air speeds so that the propeller blades don't stall, hence degrading the propulsion system's efficiency. Especially for cruising, the engine can operate in its most economical range of rotational speeds.

Self-sealing fuel tanks have multiple layers of rubber and reinforcing fabric, one of vulcanized rubber and one of untreated natural rubber that can absorb fuel and expand when wet. When a fuel tank is punctured, the fuel will seep into the layers, causing the swelling of the untreated layer, thus sealing the puncture.

In aeronautics, the rate of climb (RoC) is an aircraft's vertical speed  the rate of change in altitude. The rate of climb in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). The rate of decrease in altitude is referred to as the rate of descent or sink rate. A decrease in altitude corresponds with a negative rate of climb.

Increasing fire rate of naval guns was always troublesome due to the size of ammunition, amount of propellant charge  which greatly increase reloading time. Automating this process looks like logical step in increasing firepower of our cruisers.

Cruisers are fast, long-ranged warships, and this gives them much flexibility. However, it's important our cruisers maintain their speed advantage. More powerful engines and more efficient boilers will mean we can build faster, longer-ranged cruisers.

Installing powerful power plant on a cruiser is just a half of success when it comes to building warship that is fast and maneuverable. To ensure that designing capable screws and rudder is necessary.
With a size of average cruiser we need to start paying closer attention to hydrodymanics and how hull behaves in certain conditions.

While focused on speed and range, light cruiser still need certain level of protection to avoid being sunk by minor damage from smaller ships. Increasing thickness of their armour is easiest way to make them safe.

Heavy Cruisers often accompany bigger, better armed capital ships. Adding the fact that enemy cruiser will get better armed, it is wise to equip our newest heavy cruiser with thicker more resilient armour.

Even with having thickest, more resilient armour, some projectiles or torpedos will always defeat it. To keep our ships from sinking after receiveing only few hits we need to design system of bulkheads and watertight compartments that will prevent flooding to spread and threaten the stability of the ship.

Designing armour that covers critical areas in an efficient way is as important as it's thickness. With combat ranges increasing and growing threat posed by air attacks importance of horizontal armour never have been greater.
Better designed scheme of vertical armour will grant additional protection against projectile coming at our cruiser at flat trajectories, torpedoes and near misses.

No navy that wants to be considered modern can allow it's cruisers, ships that initialy were created as scouts for the fleets, not be equipped with surface radars. This new invention helps with detecting enemy ships even in bad weather conditions and in pitch black darkness.

With rapid development of airplanes and them becoming bigger threat to ships it became paramount to detect them as soon as possible. New models of radars will have to be designed specifically for this task.

Proper damage control techniques and training can save even most damaged ship or keep it combat ready. New procedures are created based on experience from training and actual reports from damaged ships.

Having lots of big guns doesn't mean anything if you can't hit the target. Newest developments in computing machines are extremely helpful when it comes to calculating countless variables needed to accurately hit the target that is few miles away.

Hitting fast, nimble object like a plane is very different task than hitting comparably slow and big target like ship. This requires sophisticated calculating machine that can track and calculate solution for such fast moving targets.

Airfoce importance grew immensly during recent years to the point that having enough AAA in our fleets became more important than ability to fight enemy ship directly. For that reason we can rebuild our ships into units focused more onto that new role.

This category covers all heavy (75mm+) calibers of AA guns mounted on small ships in AA role. With some investment here we can design beter AA guns, find ways to install more of them and with better firing arcs.

The battleship is the most powerful, best-protected and slowest ship afloat.  They are immensely expensive but can crush any lighter ship that comes in their way.  However, losing a battleship would be a disaster for our navy, so make sure they are always well supported by destroyers and cruisers.
After researching all required components we can start planning how to put them together and design battleship that will be better than anything that our navy had before.

The battlecruiser is a ligher, faster cousin of the battleship.  It lacks the firepower and endurance of a battleship, but is considerably cheaper, and still capable of sinking any lighter ship which comes near it.  The battlecruiser is particularly good for raiding convoys.
After researching all required components we can start planning how to put them together and design battlecruiser that will be better than anything that our navy had before.
After researching all required components we can start planning how to put them together and design PBB's that will be better than anything that our navy had before.

Main propulsion boilers provide steam to the main propulsion turbines. The more efficient boiler is, the more power we can generate for our ship.
The ship's main propulsion turbines are designed to efficiently convert the thermal energy of steam into useful mechanical energy to propel the ship through the water.
With size of capital ships and power generated by its power plant, designing good quality propellers becomes challanging but necessary task.
Tens of thousands tons of steel, steaming 20+ knots through the sea require huge and resilient rudder, or preferably multiple ones if size of the ship requires it.

Even so, they can be sunk, particularly by aircraft.  The resources needed to build these super-ships will be a huge drain on our economy.
A fast battleship utilizes the speed of a battlecruiser without sacrificing armour or armament. These ships can keep up with a carrier battlegroup.

As naval aircraft become more important, we need to put more planes on our aircraft carriers.  We can only do this by designing larger hangers, with more space for aircraft and their equipment.  Doing this will mean we can fit more planes on aircraft carriers and escort carriers.
Escort Carriers are smaller versions of aircraft carriers based on transport hulls.  They were used primarily in the Atlantic theater to form the centerpiece of ASW hunter-killer groups.

A seaplane tender (or seaplane carrier) is a ship that provides facilities for operating seaplanes. These ships are regarded by some as the first aircraft carriers and appeared just before the First World War.The seaplanes carried by the these ships provide useful long range reconnaissance patrols. Until radar becomes more widespread and powerful, patrol aircraft are the eyes of the fleet.

The HMS Illustrious class were the first carriers to incorporate their flight decks into the superstructure. This meant the flight deck, rather than the lower hangar deck was armoured, leading to much better resistance to aerial attack.
Supercarrier is an unofficial descriptive term for the largest type of aircraft carrier, usually displacing over 70,000 long tons. Supercarriers are the largest warships ever built.

Proper damage control techniques and training can save even most damaged ship or keep it combat ready. New procedures are created based on experience from training and actual reports from damaged ships.
By moving elevator slightly to the side and eventualy outside of hangar we can increase amount of planes that our newly designed carriers can carry and increase structural strength of flight deck.

Since take off space on carriers is rather limited we need to assist our planes with hydraulic catapults that will launch our planes which will require far less space on flight deck. Researching this tech will be required if Heavy Planes were chosen as an airplane focus and for higher levels of Carrier Aircraft Prototype tech.
With this aproach hangar is build as a superstructure. Open sides allow warming up planes, better venting and working condition in hot weather. It also allows installing off center elevators.
Hangar is build as a part of main structure and is closed from all sides. This approach provides additional structural strength and allows armouring of flight deck, but limits CAG size.
Closed hangar despite its positive perks requires careful approach and additional safety measures.

With hangar being integral part of main structure of a ship it is possible to arrange space for second level of hangar, which allows to compensate a bit loss of usable space and in effect increase CAG size.
By parking some planes on flight deck we can increase amount of planes on our carriers without actualy rebuilding or designing completely new ships.

After researching various CV related technologies you will reach requirements to trigger an event that will grant you ability to put extra CAG on your CV's. This tech can't upgrade so it won't affect your older CV's or the ones that are currently in the production queue.
 List of technologies required to trigger event:
 1. Deck Park, Folding Wings lvl 1. 
 2. Side Elevator, Folding Wings lvl 2. 
 3. Double Hangar lvl 1, Folding Wings lvl 2. 
 4. Double Hangar lvl 2, Deck Park.

Dual Purpose Guns were designed to allow ships to be more flexible when engaging enemy ships or planes. Having one gun that can do both jobs saves space and weight which opens additional options for installing extra armour, loading more fuel, ammunition or simply installing more guns.
Growing threat from enemy submarines might require from us specialising our destroyers in fighting against this type of threat instead more surface oriented approach.

Modern approach to the idea as old as naval combat itself - sending small fleets or often single warship to disrupt enemy shipping. This might feel pointless in the era of submarines, radars and airplanes, but single capital ship can paralyze entire convoy system if left unchecked.
